data.title: Whereabouts of paintings 1933-45
data.meta_description: A list of paintings with incomplete provenance for the years 1933-45.
data.text:
List of works with incomplete provenance from 1933–1945

In the light of concern that some works of art now in public collections may have been improperly acquired during the period 1933–1945, without restitution having been made, the National Gallery has paid particular attention to the whereabouts of its paintings during those years.

Part of the National Gallery's normal work is to investigate the whereabouts of its paintings from the time they were painted until the time they entered the Gallery's collection.

This may reveal material of great historical interest concerning, for example, the identity of the painter, the purpose for which the picture was painted, and changing patterns of collecting taste.

In March 1999, with the cooperation of the Gallery, The Art Newspaper published an initial list of paintings in the Gallery with incomplete provenance information for the period 1933–1945. Since then the Gallery's research has continued and the list has been updated from time to time and made available to any member of the public on request.

As at 17 December 2018, the Gallery had not received any claims asserting on behalf of another or others that any of the paintings on its list was looted or otherwise improperly acquired, nor was it aware of any such claim in process.

If further information is needed in respect of any particular painting, please in the first instance email information@nationalgallery.org.uk

*Early provenances for pictures are not given. NG numbers are inventory numbers. (D) signifies dealer.

‘Chalets at Rigi’

Presented by Mr Asbjørn Lunde through the American Friends of the National Gallery in recognition of the directorship of Sir Nicholas Penny, 2020

NG 6688

Provenance

Maria Gillhausen, dealer in Munich, by July 1943;{1}[1] sold to Galerie Maria Almas-Dietrich for Hitler’s projected museum (Führermuseum) at Linz, July 1943;[2] probably Führerbau, Munich (no. 2930); [3] stored in the salt mine at Altaussee in Austria, from around 1944-5;[4] brought to the Central Collecting Point, Munich (no. 9683), 15 October 1945;[5] transferred to the State Premier of Bavaria, 31 August 1948; transported from Munich to Salzburg and then brought to a depot of the Austrian Federal Authority, 18 January 1952; ownership transferred to Austria for disposition, 22 July 1955; moved to the Kartause Mauerbach, Mauerbach, 1966;[6] on deposit at the Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna (inv. 9734), from 1979; transferred to the Federal Association of Jewish Religious Communities in Austria, 31 October 1995;[7] purchased by Asbjørn Lunde [1927-2017] (Mauerbach: Items seized by the National Socialists to be sold for the benefit of the Victims of the Holocaust, Christie’s, Vienna, lot 317, as follower of Calame), 29-30 October 1996;[8] on long term loan to the National Gallery, 2011; gift to the National Gallery, 2020.

Notes

[1] Information from records of the Special Commission Linz, no. 2930 (A. Enderlein, M. Flacke and H. C. Löhr, ‘Datenblatt LI002939’, Datenbank ”Sammlung des Sonderauftrages Linz”, https://www.dhm.de/datenbank/linzdb/indexe.html, Berlin, 2008 (search for Single Object no. 2930 (accessed 22 September 2021)) and Munich Central Collecting Point (CPP) Property Card – Inventory BDA (Austria), no. 9683 (A. Enderlein and M. Flacke, Datenbank zum “Central Collecting Point München”, https://www.dhm.de/datenbank/ccp/dhm_ccp.php?seite=9, Berlin, 6 June 2009 (accessed 21 September 2021)).

[2] Information from Special Collection Linz records and Munich CPP Card, as in note 1.

[3] Number 36 in Album XXVI of the photographic albums assembled for Hitler, this one dispatched from Dresden to Hitler on 3 November 1943: Alexandre Calame, Blick von einer Alm auf den Pilatus. B. Schwarz, Hitlers Museum. Die Fotoalben Gemäldegalerie Linz: Dokumente zum ‘Führermuseum’, Vienna 2004.

[4] Information from Munich CPP Card, as in note 1.

[5] Information from Munich CPP Card, as in note 1.

[6] Implied by the painting’s inclusion in the ‘Mauerbach Sale’, as in note 7.

[7] Implied by the painting’s inclusion in the ‘Mauerbach Sale’, as in note 7.

[8] For the ‘Mauerbach Sale’, see National Fund of the Republic of Austria for Victims of National Socialism, ‘The Mauerbach Auction” of 1996’, ArtDatabase, https://www.kunstdatenbank.at/the-mauerbach-auction-of-1996 (accessed 13 May 2020); I. Seidl-Hohenveldern, ‘The Auction of the “Mauerbach Treasure”‘, International Journal of Cultural Property, vol. 6, issue 2 (July 1997), pp. 247–66.

KESSEL, JAN VAN, THE ELDER

‘Butterflies, Moths and Insects with Sprays of Common Hawthorn and Forget-Me-Not’

Gift from the collection of Willem Baron van Dedem, 2017

NG6666

Provenance

Possibly with (Kunsthandel M[arcel] Wolff, Rokin 130, Amsterdam), 1938. [1]{1}

Collection Dr Hans A. Wetzlar [1894-1976], Amsterdam, by 1959; [2]

by descent to his daughter, Marga ten Haaf-Wetzlar [1922-2013], Amsterdam;

by whom sold, (Sotheby’s, London), 9 July 2008, lot 14 (with NG6667);

from whom purchased by (Johnny van Haeften, London);

from whom purchased by Willem Baron van Dedem [1929-2015];

gift from the collection of Willem Baron van Dedem to the National Gallery, 2017.

Questions 1933-45

{1} Provenance before Wetzlar in 1959.

Notes

Klaus Ertz and Christa Nitze-Ertz, 'Die Maler Jan van Kessel', Lingen 2012, p.262, no. 379.

Peter C. Sutton, 'The Collection of Willem Baron van Dedem: A Supplement' (The Hague, 2012).

[1] The 2008 sale catalogue and Sutton 2012 cite Edith Griendl, 'Les peintres flamands de nature morte au XVIIe siècle' (Brussels, 1956), p. 176, and 2nd edn (Brussels, 1983), p. 365, no. 7, as referring to NG6667, a pair with NG6666. However, the dimensions of the painting (17 x 22.5 cm) given there for the work with Kunsthandel M. Wolff in 1938 do not correspond with either NG6666 or NG6667. Therefore their provenance before being purchased by Wetzlar should be considered uncertain.

[2] Hans Alfred Wetzlar was active in the art trade from about 1940; it is not clear exactly when he began to form his personal collection of 15th- to 17th-century paintings. As the paintings by van Kessel, NG6666 and NG6667, do not appear in the catalogue of the Wetzlar collection published in 1952, it is very possible that they were acquired after that date.
